title: What Does ASL Mean? Snapchat, Texting, and More

steps.title: "ASL" means â€œage, sex, locationâ€ as a standalone question.
steps.content: "ASL" means â€œage, sex, locationâ€ as a standalone question. If someone just says â€œASL?â€ and you donâ€™t know who they are, theyâ€™re asking for your age, sex, and location. By location, they mean geographic locationâ€”not where you are in your home, school, or workplace. Donâ€™t give your address or specific location. Them: â€œASL?â€ You: â€œ19, Male, Franceâ€ ASL is often abbreviated as â€œA/S/Lâ€ or â€œA, S, Lâ€ (and occasionally just â€œaslâ€). These mean the same thing. This usage of ASL is usually capitalized, but some people will just keep it lowercase.

steps.title: "Asl" means "as hell" if itâ€™s a friend messaging you or itâ€™s used in a sentence.
steps.content: "Asl" means "as hell" if itâ€™s a friend messaging you or itâ€™s used in a sentence. Asl is a contraction of â€œas hell,â€ and it can be used to emphasize something the same way you might say â€œlike crazy,â€ or, â€œseriously.â€ For example, if someone says â€œIâ€™m tired asl,â€ it would just mean â€œIâ€™m tired as hell,â€ which would just mean, â€œIâ€™m really tired.â€ Someone might say: â€œDid you see the new kid at school? Theyâ€™re cute asl.â€ â€œPeople think Iâ€™m joking, but Iâ€™m serious asl.â€ If you really canâ€™t tell which version someone is using, you can replace the â€œaslâ€ in their sentence with â€œas hell.â€ If it still makes sense, theyâ€™re using it as a contraction. This version of â€œaslâ€ is almost never capitalized.

steps.title: â€Age, sex, locationâ€ is the most common usage of "ASL" on Omegle.
steps.content: â€Age, sex, locationâ€ is the most common usage of "ASL" on Omegle. This video chat service connects you with strangers all over the globe, and people often start conversations with â€œASL?â€ to get your basic info up front. They may not want to speak to someone of another gender, or they may be trying to avoid talking to someone who doesnâ€™t speak their language. [1] X Research source Them: â€œA/S/L?â€ You: â€œHey! 18, Girl, Canadaâ€

steps.title: On social media or over text, â€œas hellâ€ is the most prevalent usage of "asl."
steps.content: On social media or over text, â€œas hellâ€ is the most prevalent usage of "asl." People donâ€™t typically ask for your age, sex, and location on social media since they can just click on your profile and get that info. If someone uses â€œaslâ€ in a text convo with you or on Instagram, itâ€™s a contraction for, â€œas hell.â€ [2] X Research source â€œIâ€™m tired asl, I donâ€™t think Iâ€™m coming out tonight.â€ â€œThis sounds fun asl! We gotta take a road trip together soon.â€

steps.title: Use ASL to get someone's basic demographics.
steps.content: Use ASL to get someone's basic demographics. If someone you donâ€™t recognize sends you a message on Snapchat, you could send them â€œASL?â€ to ask them to identify themselves. You might send this if youâ€™d be potentially interested in chatting with someone so long as theyâ€™re a certain age or gender, or if you only want to meet people near you. If youâ€™re messaging someone you donâ€™t know, you might just message them, â€œASL?â€ Theyâ€™d reply with something like â€œ22, F, California. U?â€ The implication with â€œASL?â€ is that youâ€™re open to chatting with strangers. If you want to know who someone actually is or how they found you, message them â€œDo I know you?â€ or â€œWho are you?â€ instead.

steps.title: Use asl to emphasize a feeling.
steps.content: Use asl to emphasize a feeling. If you want to use the â€œas hellâ€ version of asl, drop it in a sentence the same place youâ€™d normally say â€œlike crazyâ€ or â€œby a lot.â€ This is a casual way of highlighting the way you feel about something. For example: â€œCan we go get Mexican food? Iâ€™m hungry asl.â€ â€œIâ€™m happy asl that you agreed to go on a date w me ğŸ˜Šâ€ â€œIâ€™m so heated rn. Iâ€™m sitting in math and James is being annoying asl.â€ â€œYou trying to go out tonight? Iâ€™m bored asl just sitting at home.â€

steps.title: List your age, sex, and location in that order.
steps.content: List your age, sex, and location in that order. ASL is sort of like three individual questions, and most people just respond to asl by listing each of the answers in a row. You donâ€™t need to put them into a complete sentence or anything; this way, the person asking can know right away if the two of you are a good match to chat. Them: â€œASL?â€ You: â€œ25, Girl, Ohioâ€ People usually donâ€™t list the city they live in for the â€œlocationâ€ part unless itâ€™s a major city.

steps.title: If you arenâ€™t comfortable with it, donâ€™t share your ASL.
steps.content: If you arenâ€™t comfortable with it, donâ€™t share your ASL. If you donâ€™t know who youâ€™re talking to or you donâ€™t want to share any information with a stranger, donâ€™t. Itâ€™s possible that the person messaging you is just someone your age looking for someone to talk to, but itâ€™s also possible that itâ€™s just some creep. If you donâ€™t want to engage, donâ€™t. If someone messages you â€œASL?â€ you can say, â€œWho are you?â€ â€œSorry, I donâ€™t give that information out,â€ or, â€œUhh, do I know you?â€ If you donâ€™t want strangers to message you on Snapchat, go into your mobile number and email settings, and disable the â€œlet others find meâ€ option so that random people canâ€™t message you. Then, scroll down to â€œcontact meâ€ and change it to â€œmy friends.â€

steps.title: Provide your age, sex, and location in the chat.
steps.content: Provide your age, sex, and location in the chat. Simply list how old you are, your gender, and where you live. If you want to know about them, you can ask the same thing back. Donâ€™t worry about using complete sentences or anythingâ€”just list your info. Them: â€œASL?â€ You: â€œ26, Male, Wisconsin. You?â€

steps.title: ASL might be short for American Sign Language.
steps.content: ASL might be short for American Sign Language. This isnâ€™t going to be a super common usage over text, on Snapchat, or on social media, but ASL could be short for â€œAmerican Sign Language.â€ ASL is a gesture-based language used by people are deaf or hard of hearing to communicate. [3] X Research source Someone might say: â€œDo you know ASL?â€ â€œIâ€™m trying to learn ASL so that I can talk to my deaf nephew.â€

steps.title: Be wary of sharing info with older users if youâ€™re under 18.
steps.content: Be wary of sharing info with older users if youâ€™re under 18. There are no age restrictions on Snapchat and Omegle, and there are bad people out there who ask â€œASL?â€ at the start of conversations with strangers to look specifically for younger people. If a stranger messages you â€œASL?â€ and youâ€™re uncomfortable, donâ€™t respond. [4] X Research source Omegle in particular is probably not appropriate for younger users. If youâ€™re a parent, you may be better off blocking the site in your home. There tends to be a lot of sexual content on the platform. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Donâ€™t share specific personal information.
steps.content: Donâ€™t share specific personal information. The other concern with â€œASL?â€ is that it could be a scammer looking for victims. Thereâ€™s nothing especially dangerous about giving someone your age, gender, and general location (like your state or country), but if someone goes fishing for more specific info beyond that, donâ€™t give it out. Keep it vague whenever someone asks for your location. Itâ€™s okay to say if you live in Michigan for example, but donâ€™t give someone the street you live on or your actual address. Never share passwords, phone numbers, or other personal data online.
